title: Is it possible to switch my current HDD for an SSD? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, you can replace the HDD in your laptop with an SSD. In fact this a very good decision to upgrade your laptop with an SSD. SSD is 5 to 25 times faster than HDD depending on what it is writing or reading. A great pleasant comes with smooth running. How to replace it? At first, I recommend you check the upgradability of your laptop as you didn’t mention your laptop model. Upgradability means easy access is provided to your hard drive via a removable panel. Check it on the bottom of your laptop. If it is sealed, follow the laptop manual for instructions an find the right replacement drive. Now follow the process: 1. Buy the right SSD (matching form factor interface). Make sure that the replacement SSD will fit your laptop. Follow your laptop manual or check specifications of your laptop on the internet to buy the right size SSD having a proper interface. You can also consult with the seller. Just go to a trusted shop and buy branded SSD. Buy a SATA to USB data transfer cable also to connect the SSD to your laptop. You should have an external HDD if you have large files and a lot of folders to take backup. I think you have a small screwdriver in your home. 2. Clone your hard drive: Install a drive cloning software.Connect the SATA to USB data transfer cable to your laptop (choose USB 3.0 port, for faster transfer).Plug the SSD into the SATA cable.Follow the instructions of the cloning application to clone your old hard disk.3. After cloning, install the SSD: Unplug the cable and SSD. Disconnect the power supply and remove the battery if it is removable.Open the laptop case and remove the screw from the mounting bracket that is holding your old HDD and remove it. Set the new SSD into it and slide it into the connectors on your laptop. Then fix the screws with the mounting bracket back into your laptop. Now set the laptop case.Install the drive management program if it is provided by the manufacturer. It keeps your drive firmware up to date and allows to customize necessary settings It is done! Now enjoy the smooth performance of your laptop because of the new SSD.

As it has been already pointed out, you can. Just remember that they haven’t been able to solve the problem of memory cell degradation. Every time you write to an SSD, you are actually slowly damaging it. It may take years (depending on how heavily you use it), but it will eventually fail. The best setup is to have a small SSD, which you keep your operating system and essential files on (drivers, utilities that you use a lot, etc), and keep everything else… especially the operating system’s “swap file”… on a conventional HDD. That way, almost the only time you write to the SSD is when you’re installing OS updates. You get super-fast booting (which is the main reason most people install an SSD), but it’ll last much longer than if you use it as your only drive.  Alternately, use a Hybrid SSD, where the actual data is stored on an HDD and frequently-used data is cached on a small SSD built into the drive. That way, if the SSD part of it fails, you’re not losing everything. Don’t be misled by the MTBF (Mean Time Between Failure). TBW (Total Bytes Written) is a more reliable specification. First of all, MTBF is “fuzzy math”… it’s only an estimate. Secondly, different manufacturers use different workloads as an estimate. For example, Intel assumes a workload of 20 GB per day for 5 years. Samsung might use an entirely different workload to calculate its MTBF. And thirdly, it’s misleading… let’s say a drive has an MTBF of 1.2 million hours (which is about 170 years). That doesn’t mean it’s going to last 1.2 million hours; in fact, it has an 0.3% chance of failing within its warranty period.
